utterances: NPR's Luke Burbank has been reporting from Las Vegas this week.
He joins us now.
Luke, where are you exactly?
And what is the latest on this story?
Alex, I'm actually in the parking lot of a McCormick and Schmick's Restaurant, just off the Vegas Strip.
And it's not because I'm getting an early start on happy hour.
It's because this is actually the spot where last Friday, Jim Gibbons and one of his main political aides and some friends were having dinner.
At some point during that night, they were joined by a couple of women who had recognized Jim Gibbons and bought them a round of drinks.
They had a couple more drinks together, and then at about 10:00 o'clock that night, that's where things get sort of murky.
Jim Gibbons says that basically he went back to his hotel room.

One of the women in that party, she contends that he basically stalked her back towards her car into the parking garage and then grabbed her and sort of tried to get her to go back to his hotel room before she ran away.
Her name is Chrissy Mazzeo and she's a 32-year-old cocktail waitress at the Wynn Hotel and Casino.
She's also a single mother.
She said that at the beginning of the night she actually didn't even know who Jim Gibbons was - this is according to her statement to police - but that her friend actually recognized him.
They sent some drinks over to Gibbons' table and then were invited over there.

And then Mazzeo says that after that, as she was trying to leave later in the night, Jim Gibbons basically followed her back to the parking garage and sort of grabbed her, accosted her, and tried to get her to go back to his hotel room.
She told the 911 operator that everyone at the table had been having a few drinks.
(Soundbite of recording)
Had he been drinking?
Yeah, he had been, and so have I.
He didn't seem like he was under the influence of anything other than alcohol, correct?
Probably power.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't know.
Well, so what is Congressman Gibbons saying about this?
Does he deny having met this woman that night?
No, he doesn't deny that he met her.
He says, though, that they came over to the table.
Their conversation was very appropriate.
In fact, he held a press conference yesterday.
At that press conference he produced three sworn affidavits from other people who were at the meal - including this woman, Chrissy Mazzeo's friend - saying that he was not drunk.
According to Gibbons' version of events, what happened was he was leaving the restaurant.
This woman came out, couldn't find her car.
He offered to help her find her car.
And at some point as they were walking towards it, she sort of drunkenly stumbled.
And that's when he caught her.
I caught her as she did so, and I asked her if she was all right.
She looked at me, said nothing, and simply walked away.
I turned and proceeded to my hotel, and that's where I remained for the rest of the night.
Well, so what do people in Nevada think?

Well, Alex, on both sides there's certainly a healthy amount of suspicion about the woman's claims, because of her being obviously inebriated and the fact that she has decided not to press any charges.

But even before that, a lot of people around the country were watching this race closely, because the Democratic Caucus in Nevada has been moved up to the number two in the nation, just after Iowa, meaning that whoever becomes governor - be it Republican or Democrat - will have an important role in who becomes the Democratic nominee in 2008.
NPR's Luke Burbank in Las Vegas.
Luke, thank you.
Sure, Alex.
I'm Mike Pesca in New York.
To true hexakosioihexekonta-hexaphobes, those who fear 666, tomorrow is a day that comes once a century never to be thought of again, after what must be a tense 24 hours.
But to another group, 6-6-06 is a day that will live on forever.
These folks aren't with us yet.
They're the ones who are to be born tomorrow: The babies of The Beast.
(Soundbite of song, "Number of the Beast")
(Singing) 666, the number of the Beast.
Hell and fire was spawned and released…
(Soundbite of children singing)
(Singing) …bake our bread, bake our bread.
This is the way we bake our bread so early…
In the movie The Omen, young Damien was born of the jackal.
Tomorrow, a new baby is set to be born of Michelle Michlik(ph) of Fairfax County, Virginia.
I would be proud, whoever my son is.
And if the anti-Christ is who he is, you know, that's who he's going to be.
Actually, Michelle dodged the Beelza-bullet.
After we taped that interview, her son came a little early.
It's easy for her, then, to be raveling in the Book of Revelation's base coincidence.
She's something of a hexakosioihexekonta-hexaphile.
But for moms with due dates on or around June 6th, there is worry.
Not necessarily that their child will actually be the Son of Perdition, the Lord of Lies, the Dark One, Belial - but that their child will be teased.
And as a mere mortal, have no dark powers with which to smite his tormentors.
Mary Supinger(ph) of Redding, California is eight-plus months pregnant.
I don't think it would bother us too much.
I think in the future, I would worry about him having to constantly write down 6-6-06 as his birth date.
So I think if given the choice, we probably would prefer not to give birth on that date, just for that sake.
But Supinger is not willing to induce labor to avoid that date.
In fact, there is some debate within the obstetrics community about the wisdom of inducing labor, or scheduling a caesarian section, just on a patient's whim.
Then again, what's superstition to a doctor might be firm religious belief to a mother.
Rachel Masch is the associate director of the Family Planning Division of the NYU Medical Center.
She has no patients who have asked to be induced to avoid 6-6-06.
But in her career, she has heard just about every other reason for inducing birth.
The classic one is people who want to be delivered before New Year for tax reasons.
And there are all sorts of other reasons: going away on vacation.
There're people whose partners may be going overseas.
There're people who have a favorite relative that had been born on a certain day that had recently died.
Many June mothers-to-be who gather in Internet chat rooms to discuss the 666 birthday have displayed a keen knowledge of numerology, notices the very pregnant A.J.
Walsh.
Ms.
A.J.
WALSH: And then there's the people in the camp that says, oh, well, technically - and I love how everybody becomes, you know, Gregorian calendar expert - well, technically it's 06-06-2006.
So unless it was six A.D., that birth date doesn't mean anything.
So, you know, had this happened a couple thousand years ago, you know, it would clearly be cause for concern.
If you were going to buy a Nook you would already have a Kindle, is basically the way I feel about it.
If you really want to be technical, many scholars who have examined the original Greek, from which the Bible was written, say that 666 is actually a mistranslation.
It's actually 616, a relief to anyone born tomorrow, but a classic bit of satanic misdirection, getting everyone nervous about June 6th when he really slipped through the door four days ago, 6-1-06.
Mike Pesca, NPR News, New York.

NPR's DAY TO DAY continues.
The discovery of explosives on those cargo planes has led to calls for tougher screening of air freight.
U.S.
carriers have already been ramping up security of cargo that travels on passenger planes since Congress passed new requirements in 2007.
But, as NPR's Larry Abramson reports, shippers say that screening everything shipped by air would slow things down and cost lots of money.
The 9/11 Commission recommended screening of all cargo that goes on passenger planes.
So back in 2007, Democratic Congressman Ed Markey helped pass a law that requires total inspections starting in August of this year.
Now, Markey says this most recent incident is a sign Congress should go further.
It does not have to be identical to cargo carried on domestic planes, but I don't think we can be completely reliant upon intelligence provided to us by Saudi Arabia or other countries.
Brandon Fried represents shippers as head of the Airforwarders Association, an industry group.
He says that just inspecting the seven billion pounds a year that goes on commercial flights is already very expensive.
We've invested, you know, hundreds of millions of dollars in the last few years to accomplish the task that was mandated by the 9/11 legislation.
